E la restauracio de totas las manieyras de lu es que fassas cezer le malaute dreyt, enayssi que ja extenda la sieua camba, si pot sobre aquo; adherir le tieu dos a la cara de lu, e pausa le pe de lu entre les tieus pes; e aprop fay adherir le denol de lu am las tuas palmas, e rete aquelas entre les tieus ditz sobre le denolh de lu am fortaleza, e autre ministre extenda le sieu pe entro que·l denol retorne a son loc.	And the treatment for all types of knee dislocations is to have the patient lie down and extend their leg if possible; then place your hand on the back of the knee and hold the patient's foot between your legs, while using both palms to press firmly on the front of the knee and applying steady pressure with your fingers. Another assistant should slowly straighten the patient's leg until the knee returns to its proper position.
E senhal de reddicio de lu es que la sua camba adharesca am la coyssa am levitat no-laboroza.	And the sign that the reduction is successful is when the patient's leg attaches easily and effortlessly to their thigh.
E aprop emplastra aquel e fay adhirir la camba am la coyssa, e aprop lia aquelas emsemps am una benda per tres dias o per quatre, e aprop deslia aquelas.	And then apply bandages to immobilize the knee and hold it in place against the thigh for three or four days; then remove the bandages.
E no uze le malaute de ambulacio per alcus dias, entro que sia sanat e cofortat.	And instruct the patient to avoid walking for several days until they have regained their strength and are fully healed.
Mays si la reduccio de lu a tu es excusada, lahoras aministra fort extencio am liamentz dels quals en la curacio de la hancha precedit narracio.	But if the reduction is unsuccessful, then apply strong traction with ligaments as described earlier in the treatment of a dislocated hip.
Capitol .xxxiii.	Capital XXXIII. (This would be the title of the next section or chapter)
De la curacio de la dislocacio del talo.	Of the healing of the dislocation of the ankle. (based on the context, it seems that this text is describing a medical procedure for treating a dislocated ankle)
Le talo alcunas veguadas es remaugut per petita remocio, e alcunas veguadas es dislocat segon compliment, e la dislocacio de lu es fayta o a las partidas dedintz o a las partidas deforo.	The ankle can sometimes be dislocated due to a small displacement, and at other times it is dislocated as a result of its normal movement, and such a dislocation can occur either within or outside the joint.
E le senhal de la dislocacio de lu es que vezes le talo imflat procedent a la partida a la qual es dislocat.	And the sign of ankle dislocation is that sometimes the ankle appears swollen, proceeding towards the part where it is dislocated.
Mays la curacio de la remocio de lu es de leugiera reddicio, e es que sia extendut am facilitat am las mas e sia engualhat entro que retorne.	But the healing of the displacement (small dislocation) is easy to reduce, and this involves extending it with ease using one's hands and bandaging it until it returns to its proper position.
Mays en la curacio de lu quan es dislocat segon compliment, cove que fasses cezer le malaute dreyt, e tengua aquel un ministre fort e valent de la partida detras del dos de aquel en le mieg loc de lu.	But in healing when it is dislocated as a result of its normal movement, it is necessary to lay the patient flat and have a strong and capable assistant stand behind him at the affected side in the middle of his back.
E aprop te tu am la tieua ma dreyta le pe de la pus sobirana part, e am la tua ma sinistra de la part pus dejos del pe en le loc de la cavilha.	Then place your right hand on the upper part of the leg and your left hand below the leg at the level of the ankle joint.
E aprop atira le pe a tu am la tua ma dreyta, e aprop am la sinistra per dos veguadas, e aprop exten am la sinistra; e empelleys le pietz del pe am la dreyta deves la camba ses trebalh.	Then pull the leg towards you with your right hand and apply pressure with both hands for two movements, and extend it using your left hand; and push the heel of the foot towards the thigh with your right hand.
E fay aquo doas veguadas segon que havem comtat.	And do this twice as I have described.
E aprop empelleys le pietz del pe a la camba la tersa veguada, e tu es a la cavilha.	Then push the heel of the foot towards the thigh for the third time and place your hand at the ankle joint. (it seems that this step is repeating the same movement described earlier but with one less repetition)
Donc si retorna en una veguada o en dos segon aquesta manieyra, e si vezes le pe engualhat, es bo; e sino, lahoras sobre lu itera la operacio, quar aquel retorna.	So if it returns to its proper position in one or two movements following this method, and sometimes the foot will be swollen, that is good; but if not, then you should repeat the procedure because it will eventually return to its proper position. (This sentence is summarizing the previous instructions for reducing an ankle dislocation and adding a note about possible swelling)
Mays si a tu es prohibida la reduccio de lu am aquo que havem recomtat, lahoras fay jaser le malaute sobre le sieu dos sobre terra, e estrenh un paysel mot en terra fermat, e que caja entre las coyssas de lu, e tu ja has envolopat sobre lu drap per so que no ledesca le malaute.	But if you are not authorized to reduce it (the dislocation) using the method described above, then have the patient lie on his back on the ground, place a firm cushion under his buttocks, and position it between his thighs; then wrap him in a blanket so that he does not feel cold. (This sentence is providing an alternative non-invasive treatment option when reducing a dislocation is not recommended or possible)
E aprop le ministre de lu tengua las suas coyssas, e aprop autre ministre extenda le pe am las suas mas o am liament que lie sobre le col del pe; e aprop extenda aquel quascun ministre contre extencio del sieu par, e le payssel sia extant entre las coyssas del malaute retinent aquel, per so que·l cos de lu no sia atirat a las partidas dejos deves la sua extencio.	And let the assistant of the patient hold his thighs, and let another assistant extend the leg with their hands or using a bandage that surrounds the lower leg; and let each assistant pull on the opposite side of the leg to prevent it from being extended too much, while keeping the cushion between the patient's thighs to stabilize his body and prevent it from being pulled downwards by the leg extension. (This sentence is describing a non-invasive method for stretching the leg in order to reduce a dislocation, where assistants provide support and countertraction)
E aprop le metge enguala la dislocacio am las sieuas mas, e autre ministre tengua la coyssa sana a las partidas dejos, quar la dislocacio retorna am la facilitat.	And let the doctor bandage the dislocation with his hands and another assistant hold the healthy thigh towards the lower end, because the dislocation will return easily (to its proper position). (This sentence is describing a manual reduction technique where the doctor uses their hands to manipulate the affected joint and move it back into place while an assistant holds the other side in order to stabilize the limb)
E donc cum retorna la dislocacio e es declarada a tu la sanetat de la reduccio de lu, lahoras pausa emplastre e extrenh aquela am liamentz fortment, e ligua le pe am liament a la camba.	And when the dislocation returns to its proper position and you are certain that it is healed, then apply a poultice and bandage it firmly, and bind the leg to the thigh using a strong bandage. (This sentence is summarizing the treatment steps for ankle dislocation and providing instructions on how to immobilize the joint after reduction)
E cove que temes o te guardes dels nervis les quals so detras sobre le talo, per que le liament sobre aquel no sia vehement e leda aquel fortment.	And you should be careful and protect the nerves that are located behind the ankle, because a strong bandage on top of them can cause damage or severe pain. (This sentence is providing a cautionary note about potential complications that may arise from applying a bandage too tightly or incorrectly)
E aprop layssa aquel per dos dias o per tres; e si le liament es mollificat, extrenh aquel.	And let it remain (bandaged) for two or three days; and if the bandage becomes soft, remove it. (This sentence is providing instructions on how long to leave the bandage in place and when to replace it with a new one)
E aprop deslia aquel en le ters dia o en le quart, e prohibeys le malaute de anament per xl dias.	And unwrap (the bandage) on the third or fourth day and forbid the patient to walk for 40 days. (This sentence is providing instructions on when to remove the bandage and how long the patient should avoid weight-bearing activities in order to promote healing and prevent re-injury)
Mays si es forsat de anar denant aquel spazi, no es fayta segurtat que la dislocacio no sia sobre lu dissolvuda e corrumpuda, e aprop aquo que no recipia curacio.	But if he is forced to walk before the recommended time, there is a risk that the dislocation may become unstable and infected, leading to delayed or incomplete healing. (This sentence is emphasizing the importance of complying with medical advice and avoiding weight-bearing activities for the recommended duration)
E si accideys a lu apostema caut, lahoras cove que tu aministre en la cedacio de lu aquo en lo qual precedic la nostra narracio, en autre loc de curacio e de embrocacio, entro que sia remauguda.	And if an abscess forms near the affected area, then it is necessary to administer treatment as described in our previous discussion, including incision and drainage, wound care, and medication until the infection resolves. (This sentence is acknowledging that complications can arise during the healing process and describing appropriate medical interventions for treating an abscess or other infection)
Capitol .xxxiiii.	Chapter XXXIV. (This heading indicates a new section in the text, likely addressing a different medical condition or treatment approach)
De curacio de dislocacio dels ditz dels pes.	Of the healing of dislocation of the toes. (This sentence is identifying the topic of the current chapter and indicating that it deals with the diagnosis and treatment of toe dislocations)
Cove que aquel qu’es dislocat sia engualhat am pauca extencio ses trebal; e aquo que no es dificil, abantz es leugier.	It is necessary that the dislocated toe be bandaged with little extension without effort; and this is not difficult, it can be done easily. (This sentence is describing a basic treatment approach for reducing a toe dislocation, which involves applying gentle traction to realign the affected joint and immobilizing it using a dressing or bandage)
Mays si la dislocacio es en alcus nozes del dos del pe, lahoras cove que fassas cezer le malaute le sieu pe sobre loc engual de la terra o sobre taula, e sia estant ayssi cum si anava.	But if the dislocation is in one of the middle toes of the foot, then it is necessary to lay the patient's foot on a flat surface or table, and keep it in the same position as if he were walking normally. (This sentence is describing a different reduction technique for treating a toe dislocation that involves manipulating the affected joint while the foot is in a weight-bearing position) [*]
E aprop tu sta de pes, e pausa le tieu pe sobre aquo que imineys de las juncturas, e aprop calca aquel am le tieu pe am vertut entro que retorne, e que vejas aquel ja engualhat e no aparesca en le loc eminencia.	And you should stand with your weight on the opposite foot, and place your foot over the joints of the affected toe, applying gentle pressure until it returns to its proper position, and ensuring that it is well bandaged and not swollen. (This sentence is summarizing the steps for reducing a middle toe dislocation and emphasizing the importance of post-reduction care)
E aprop pausa dejos le ventre del pe de lu una taula que prengua tot le pe, a la qual sian dos caps, e aprop strenh aquel am strectura decent e ferma per tres dias; e aprop deslia aquel e fay aquel repausar de ambulacio per motz dias, entro que sia estrenhut e de reddicio sia assegurat.	And then place a table or board under the patient's foot that spans the entire length of it, with two supports at either end, and secure it firmly with gentle traction for three days; and then unwrap it and allow the patient to rest from walking for several days until it has healed and the reduction is secure. (This sentence is describing a method for immobilizing the toe after reduction and emphasizing the importance of allowing adequate time for healing before resuming normal activities)
Capitol .xxxv.	Chapter XXXV. (This heading indicates a new section in the text, likely addressing a different medical condition or treatment approach)
De las specias de dislocacio que sian faytas am plagua o am fractura o am quascuna ensemps.	Of the types of dislocation caused by injury, fracture, or both. (This sentence is identifying the topic of the current chapter and indicating that it deals with differentiating between various causes of joint injuries and how to diagnose and treat them)
Quan accideys alcuna causa de aquelas, e tu te perforssas en la curacio de aquela e en la restauracio de lu, motas veguadas succezeys la mort.	When any of these causes occur and you attempt to treat the injury and restore function, often times this results in death. (This sentence is acknowledging that severe joint injuries can have serious consequences and emphasizing the importance of careful assessment and treatment planning)
E per aquo no cove que sobre la curacio de lu presuma, sino aquel que es savi en l’art, de lonc uzatge, misericordios e pietados, tardiu, no-ardit ni presomptuos; e que use en le comensament de medicinas que cedan apostemas cautz tant solament, e leyssa le malaute al divinal jutgament, sino ad aquel al qual speras salut de perdicio, am de la malautia alleviacio, e en la qual appareys alcuna speransa.	And so it is not advisable to be overconfident in treating such injuries, but rather the wise and experienced physician who is compassionate and caring, slow to act, cautious, and humble, should use gentle medications that only occasionally cause abscesses and allow the patient to rely on divine judgement. Only treat those whose salvation from death and relief from suffering is possible, and where there is hope for a cure. (This sentence is emphasizing the importance of caution and humility in treating joint injuries, acknowledging that some cases may be beyond medical intervention and recognizing the limits of one's own abilities as a physician)
E adonc esforsa te tantost far de lu la reduccio en le comensament de la causa, denant que endevengua apostema caut.	And so you should make every effort to reduce the dislocation at the onset of the injury, before an abscess forms. (This sentence is summarizing the importance of early intervention and prompt treatment for joint injuries in order to prevent complications such as infection)
E adonc si le membre retorna segon que volem, lahoras aministra regiment le qual ceda apostema caut e cura la plagua am aquo que conveneys a lu dels enguentz desiccatius.	And if the affected limb returns to its normal position as desired, then administer treatment that prevents abscess formation and manage the injury with appropriate drying agents as needed. (This sentence is providing instructions for post-reduction care and emphasizing the importance of preventing infection and promoting healing)
E si dislocacio es am fractura e accideys en le os satagias separadas, lahoras tu perforsa le stement de lor, e fay en aquo so que havem dit en las malautias simplas de aquo que es precedit en les locz de aquels.	If the dislocation is accompanied by a fracture and there are separated bone fragments, then you should perform reduction of their position, and carry out the treatment described in previous sections for simple injuries. (This sentence is describing how to treat compound joint injuries with associated bone fractures)
E guarda e esquiva segon la tua vertut aquel del intrament en las vias de temor segon que a tu es precedida la mia predicacio; quar aquo es milhor a tu deves le tieu Creator, e mays permanent a la tua gloria, e mays saludos al tieu cos verays aquels en le tieu temps.	And protect and avoid as much as you can any internal injury in the affected limb, following my advice based on fear of complications; for this is better for your relationship with your Creator, more permanent for your glory, and truer health for your body at the right time. (This sentence is emphasizing the importance of taking precautions to prevent internal injuries during treatment and recognizing the benefits of careful medical care)
Ayssi fineysso las paraulas de Albucasim perfieytament de las quals Dieus ne sia benezeyt.	Thus ends the words of Albucasis perfectly, may God bless him (This sentence is acknowledging the source of the medical text and expressing gratitude for its wisdom)
